No official recommendation is made with regard to the use of a cent sign , and usage differs between and within member states . Sums are often expressed as decimals of the euro ( for example €0.05 or €–.05 rather than 5c ) .

Inspiration for the € symbol itself came from the
Greek epsilon ( ϵ ) – a reference to the cradle of European civilization – and the first letter of the word Europe , crossed by two parallel lines to ‘ certify ’ the stability of the euro . The official story of the design history of the euro sign is disputed by Arthur Eisenmenger , a former chief graphic designer for the European Economic Community , who claims he had the idea prior to the European Commission .
